contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} In [[mathematics]], the '''linearity of differentiation''' is a most fundamental property of the [[derivative]], in [[differential calculus]]. It follows from the [[sum rule in differentiation]] and the [[constant factor rule in differentiation]]. Thus it can be said that the act of differentiation is [[Linear map|linear]], or the [[differential operator]] is a [[Linear map|linear operator]]. Let ''f'' and ''g'' be functions, with <math>\alpha</math> and <math>\beta</math> fixed. Now consider: :<math>\frac{\mbox{d}}{\mbox{d} x} ( \alpha \cdot f(x) + \beta \cdot g(x) ) </math> By the [[sum rule in differentiation]], this is: :<math>\frac{\mbox{d}}{\mbox{d} x} ( \alpha \cdot f(x) ) + \frac{\mbox{d}}{\mbox{d} x} (\beta \cdot g(x))</math> By the [[constant factor rule in differentiation]], this reduces to: :<math>\alpha \cdot f'(x) + \beta \cdot g'(x)</math> This in turn leads to: :<math>\frac{\mbox{d}}{\mbox{d} x}(\alpha \cdot f(x) + \beta \cdot g(x)) = \alpha \cdot f'(x) + \beta \cdot g'(x)</math> Omitting the [[bracket]]s, this is often written as: :<math>(\alpha \cdot f + \beta \cdot g)' = \alpha \cdot f'+ \beta \cdot g'</math> {{DEFAULTSORT:Linearity Of Differentiation}} [[Category:Differential calculus]]
